DataElement.preferredName: Prostate Carcinoma TNM Stage Grouping Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information related to the aggregated system of clinicopathologic evaluation of prostate cancer based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A system for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage._Cancer that forms in tissues of the prostate (a gland in the male reproductive system found below the bladder and in front of the rectum). Prostate cancer usually occurs in older men.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Prostate carcinoma is one of the most common malignant tumors afflicting men.  The majority of carcinomas arise in the peripheral zone and a minority occur in the central or the transitional zone of the prostate gland.  Grossly, prostatic carcinomas appear as ill-defined yellow areas of discoloration in the prostate gland lobes.  Adenocarcinomas represent the overwhelming majority of prostatic carcinomas.  Prostatic-specific antigen (PSA) serum test is widely used as a screening test for the early detection of prostatic carcinoma.  Treatment options include radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, androgen ablation and cryotherapy.  Watchful waiting or surveillance alone is an option for older patients with low-grade or low-stage disease.  -- 2002

Concepts.definition: One of the most common malignant tumors afflicting men.  The majority of carcinomas arise in the peripheral zone and a minority occur in the central or the transitional zone of the prostate gland.  Grossly, prostatic carcinomas appear as ill-defined yellow areas of discoloration in the prostate gland lobes.  Adenocarcinomas represent the overwhelming majority of prostatic carcinomas.  Prostatic-specific antigen (PSA) serum test is widely used as a screening test for the early detection of prostatic carcinoma.  Treatment options include radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, androgen ablation and cryotherapy.  Watchful waiting or surveillance alone is an option for older patients with low-grade or low-stage disease.

Property.preferredDefinition: A system of clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment. (On-line Medical Dictionary):Stage Grouping; an assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage. (caDSR)

Concepts.definition: A system for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.
An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 11/30/2017: CM Released as part of draft content review

ValueDomain.preferredName: Prostate Carcinoma TNM Staging System Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Information related to the category of prostate cancer for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: pT3 Stage Finding NX Stage Finding M0 Stage Finding

ValueMeaning.preferredName: pT3 Stage Finding NX Stage Finding M0 Stage Finding
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic primary tumor TNM stage finding.  The definition of pT3 stage finding depends on the particular type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for breast cancer, pT3 stage finding is defined as follows: cancer with tumor size more than 5.0 cm in greatest dimension; for kidney cancer, pT3 stage finding is defined as follows: cancer with tumor extending into major veins or perinephric tissues but not into the ipsilateral adrenal gland and not beyond Gerota's fascia. (from AJCC 7th Ed.): A regional lymph node TNM finding indicating that the status of regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

Concepts.definition: A pathologic primary tumor TNM finding. The definition of pT3 finding depends on the particular type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for breast cancer, pT3 finding is defined as follows: cancer with tumor size more than 5.0 cm in greatest dimension; for kidney cancer, pT3 finding is defined as follows: cancer with tumor extending into major veins or perinephric tissues but not into the ipsilateral adrenal gland and not beyond Gerota's fascia. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)
A regional lymph node TNM finding indicating that the status of regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.
A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: pT2 Stage Finding NX Stage Finding M0 Stage Finding

ValueMeaning.preferredName: pT2 Stage Finding NX Stage Finding M0 Stage Finding
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic primary tumor TNM stage finding. The definition of pT2 stage finding depends on the particular type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for breast cancer, pT2 stage finding is defined as follows: cancer with tumor size more than 2.0 cm, but not more than 5.0 cm in greatest dimension; for colorectal cancer, pT2 stage finding is defined as follows: cancer with invasion into the muscularis propria. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.): A regional lymph node TNM finding indicating that the status of regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

Concepts.definition: A pathologic primary tumor TNM finding. The definition of pT2 finding depends on the particular type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for breast cancer, pT2 finding is defined as follows: cancer with tumor size more than 2.0 cm, but not more than 5.0 cm in greatest dimension; for colorectal cancer, pT2 finding is defined as follows: cancer with invasion into the muscularis propria. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)
A regional lymph node TNM finding indicating that the status of regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.
A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: pT1 Stage Finding NX Stage Finding M0 Stage Finding

ValueMeaning.preferredName: pT1 Stage Finding NX Stage Finding M0 Stage Finding
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic primary tumor TNM stage finding.  The definition of pT1 stage finding depends on the particular type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for breast cancer, pT1 stage finding is defined as follows: cancer with tumor size 2.0 cm or less in greatest dimension; for colorectal cancer, pT1 stage finding is defined as follows: cancer with invasion into the submucosa. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.): A regional lymph node TNM finding indicating that the status of regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

Concepts.definition: A pathologic primary tumor TNM finding. A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A system of clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment. (On-line Medical Dictionary):The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A system for clinicopathologic evaluation of tumors based on the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion), and lymph node involvement (N) and metastasis (M) each followed by a number starting at 0 for no evident metastasis; numbers used depend on the organ involved and influence the prognosis and choice of treatment.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
